posts.cooked:
Is signal still a secure platform given that Titan (intel 471) have added signal access to their software?

signal-2024-12-19-09-39-41-154753√ó1600 150 KB

See picture, also chat from one SOC claims he can see signal discussions as if he viewing them on his phone.

posts.name: kara
posts.cooked:
Hi, although their text is vague here for me this does not read like they have an attack to read every Signal chat they want, but more that they build a software to monitor what is posted in public / well-known Signal groups, that might be used by some people as a replacement for Telegram channels.
If a Signal group is public, e.g. by posting the group link on a website to attract more members, there is little Signal could do to prevent everybody, including the company mentioned above, to join the group and read all messages.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Please use links when referencing things. Asking this question and then intentionally introducing unnecessary friction to verifying what is being claimed is very shady.

Intel 471

Expanding source coverage: adding Signal chats to threat intelligence

Cybercriminals need easy ways to communicate, connect, and plan, whether they‚Äôre trading stolen credentials, rallying hacktivists, or mounting a targeted‚Ä¶

The answer is yes, Signal is the most secure messaging option that exists. The U.S. CISA and FBI even endorsed it recently:

cisa.gov

guidance-mobile-communications-best-practices.pdf

381.52 KB

The article you reference even answers your question:

Signal is known for its strong emphasis on privacy and security

Being a cyber intelligence group/website, what they‚Äôve ‚Äúcollected‚Äù are links to Signal groups posted online. Signal groups are not publicly searchable like Telegram, so the only way to find groups is if links to them are posted publicly, or through social engineering of group members.

posts.cooked:
This is what I have from a SOC team memebr

signal-2024-12-19-11-37-52-6521072√ó774 62.8 KB

That sounds pretty clear to me that they have access to any conversation

It‚Äôs not an article it‚Äôs a direct post from intel 471 to it‚Äôs Titan clients

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
degriz:

This is what I have from a SOC team memebr

There‚Äôs nothing clear about this. It‚Äôs a random message from some person you‚Äôre claiming is part of this group (with 0 proof) that made an ambiguous statement (also with 0 proof) only to you. Sorry, but your claim boils down to ‚Äútrust me, bro‚Äù.

As I said, if they can actually see the contents of group messages, the group link was either posted publicly or they socially engineered their way into them. There‚Äôs 0 possibility and/or probability that they have access to 1:1 conversations without physically holding devices where those messages are stored.

degriz:

It‚Äôs not an article it‚Äôs a direct post from intel 471 to it‚Äôs Titan clients

I was referring to your opening post with the Intel 471 website screenshot.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
even their blogpost that was linked to here doesn‚Äôt exactly seem clear about what their capabilities are.
as a matter of fact, reading through the blogpost and through the screenshot of a picture of a screen of an email, it seems more like they can now monitor Signal groups when added to them too.

The continuous coverage of messaging platform channels and groups enables customers to set up watchers against specific groups across Telegram, Discord, underground forums, and now Signal chat groups too, that create alerts for developing events customers need to observe.

this paragraph in particular doesn‚Äôt seem to imply they‚Äôve managed to break Signal, but that they‚Äôre able to monitor communication channels that they have access too to see signs of suspicious behaviour in them (for example, an account takeover by a malicious actor).

kara42:

If a Signal group is public, e.g. by posting the group link on a website to attract more members, there is little Signal could do to prevent everybody, including the company mentioned above, to join the group and read all messages.

yeah, or that. that would also explain the ‚Äúspecific groups‚Äù part.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
The Signal President has addressed this:

Mastodon ‚Äì 19 Dec 24

Meredith Whittaker (@Mer__edith@mastodon.world)

üõëü§° PSA: This is disingenuous marketing. Signal chats can't be 'monitored' by anyone not in those chats. Dressing up "joining groups via publicly posted links, then exfiltrating group data" as an offensive 'cybercapability' borders on misinfo, and...

PSA: This is disingenuous marketing. Signal chats can‚Äôt be ‚Äòmonitored‚Äô by anyone not in those chats.

Dressing up ‚Äújoining groups via publicly posted links, then exfiltrating group data‚Äù as an offensive ‚Äòcybercapability‚Äô borders on misinfo, and confuses/scares ppl who rely on Signal for robust privacy.

posts.cooked:
Avitus:

borders

If that‚Äôs what they are doing then yes I would agree that‚Äôs disingenuous. The implication in this post from intel 471 is that they have cracked the encryption at least that‚Äôs how I read it. The post says nothing about public group chats it only mentions group chats. I think you are making toany assumptions on what they mean by group chats. If you take their statement at face value then I think the implications are worrying. Of course you may be right but I don‚Äôt think this is something to be taken lightly. Titan is a very expensive platform/product and if all they are doing is joining public chats then that‚Äôs hardly an offering worth boasting about, I mean anyone can do that. Really would like a response from someone at Signal.
I hope you are right

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
degriz:

The implication in this post from intel 471 is that they have cracked the encryption

With no proof. Where‚Äôs the proof? If they did something so exceptional they should be disclosing it to Signal responsibly, not making unverifiable claims in a blog post that amounts to ‚Äútrust me, bro‚Äù. No declaration of anything holds merit without verifiable proof.

degriz:

I think you are making toany assumptions on what they mean by group chats.

I‚Äôm applying simple common sense, not assuming anything. When you create a Signal group, you can associate it with a link, and then post that link publicly on the Internet to grow membership. It sounds like publicly posted links were found and there is little or no scrutiny applied to people joining the group.

degriz:

If you take their statement at face value then I think the implications are worrying.

And if you apply the smallest scrutiny to the claim, it‚Äôs baseless. There is no substance without verifiable proof.

degriz:

I don‚Äôt think this is something to be taken lightly.

This type of claim is made at least once every quarter, and every time it‚Äôs done in the same way: publicly, on a person‚Äôs, group‚Äôs or company‚Äôs own blog, and lacking verifiable proof. The intention behind it is probably to inflate Q4 earnings ahead of reporting annual earnings.

degriz:

Titan is a very expensive platform/product and if all they are doing is joining public chats then that‚Äôs hardly an offering worth boasting about, I mean anyone can do that.

Exactly. They made this blog post for the marketing and publicity. It‚Äôll probably blow up in the news today, they‚Äôll generate a ton of new business, and no proof will ever be produced. Or, they‚Äôll do like Cellebrite did and delete or edit the post after the business they‚Äôre hoping to generate from it dries up.

degriz:

Really would like a response from someone at Signal.

They did. Is signal still a secure platform - #9 by Avitus

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: and i hope a meteor doesn‚Äôt hit my house tomorrow. there‚Äôs always a chance for something remarkably bad to happen, doesn‚Äôt mean we should worry about it when there‚Äôs no concrete proof we‚Äôre in danger.

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked:
Quit concern trolling after intentionally trying to join in stirring up
It‚Äôs as insulting to intelligence as you already know it is and it makes you look like 10x a bigger for both knowing it and still doing it.

degriz:

I think you are making toany assumptions

You mean like this one you‚Äôre making?

degriz:

The implication in this post from intel 471 is that they have cracked the encryption

Nothing says anything about cracking encryption or otherwise accessing private chats. They‚Äôre (probably intentionally) vague, but everything points to simple monitoring of chats that anyone already has public access to.

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

You mean like this one you‚Äôre making?

They‚Äôre just being a boring and unhelpful stirrer & concern trolling
It‚Äôs y‚Äôalls call, but I recommend closing out hopefully the last rendition of this crap for the year (‚Ä¶or at least the week)

i think intel471 claims are over marketed something. maybe they have access to public channels. i don‚Äôt think they have broken the encryption or collect metadata from private conversations.

this is a good time to remind one thing, which might distantly be related.

sometimes is more important to secure underlying platform, like android, ios, windows, linux and others than having a super secure communication protocol. if underlying platform is compromised, then it is basically game over. even super secure coms cannot fix underlying platform‚Äôs deficiencies.

Nobody is mad at you for criticizing you‚Äôre being criticized for spreading FUD then acting condescending when confronted about it stop spreading nonsense and maybe you‚Äôll receive a warmer welcome.

degriz:

That sounds pretty clear to me that they have access to any conversation

They don‚Äôt. They‚Äôre talking about the format, which appears as though you‚Äôre reading the chat from the phone. I use 471.

rassilon1963:

but that they‚Äôre able to monitor communication channels

Exactly this.

degriz:

The implication in this post from intel 471 is that they have cracked the encryption

It‚Äôs clever marketing, teetering falsehoods. At best they‚Äôre disingenuous as to the capabilities.

If you‚Äôve got any groups that require a ‚Äògroup link‚Äô, well, I‚Äôd turn that off‚Ä¶.
If there‚Äôs people in a group you don‚Äôt recognise, or it‚Äôs too large to notice, then there‚Äôll be a bot scraping the data.

This is nothing new - 471 have been doing it for years. It‚Äôs just adding Signal as Telegram is not a secure platform (and never has been) but criminals were too thick to realise until the media hype. So now they‚Äôre looking for a home.

degriz:

That sounds pretty clear to me that they have access to any conversation

When I find group link and join the group, I can see all activity in the group. Cool, I‚Äôve just ‚Äúhacked‚Äù Signal! It‚Äôs incredible to be ‚Äúbreak their encryption‚Äù just like that.

Really, if they found a way to actually break encryption, they‚Äôd boast much more and say it outright instead of these imprecise claims.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
DirkPitt1:

Really, if they found a way to actually break encryption, they‚Äôd boast much more and say it outright instead of these imprecise claims.

Exactly this. Like I said above, the timing of this is such that they‚Äôre probably just trying to juice earnings before the end of the year.

Is there something in either Android or iOS that might allow their software to snoop on a clicked Signal group link? If a link is shared outside of Signal (even through secure communication), it could be vulnerable to such an exploit. With the link, the software could be able to join that group and try to go unnoticed.
